etymologies: mid 17th century. From Yiddish shames attendant from post-biblical Hebrew šammāš attendant, servant, caretaker, (specifically) sexton of a synagogue, beadle of a Beth Din, (in later use also) an extra candle used for lighting Hanukkah candles from šimmēš to serve

definitions: A ninth candle used for lighting the candles on each of the eight nights of Hanukkah.
